global_flags.description: Causes debugfs to open the device using Direct I/O, bypassing the buffer cache.  Note that some Linux devices, notably device  mapper as of this writing, do not support Direct I/O.
print the version number of debugfs and exit.

the  use  of the given block size (in bytes) for the file system, rather than detecting the correct block size automatically. (This option is rarely needed; it is used primarily when the file system is extremely badly damaged/corrupted.)

Specifies that the file system should be opened in catastrophic mode, in which the inode and group bitmaps are  not  read  initially. This  can be useful for file systems with significant corruption, but because of this, catastrophic mode forces the file system to be opened read-only.
This includes data, directory, and indirect blocks.
When debugfs is finished executing those commands, it will exit.

Specifies that device represents an ext2 image file created by the e2image program.  Since the ext2 image file only contains the  su‐ perblock,  block  group  descriptor, block and inode allocation bitmaps, and the inode table, many debugfs commands will not function properly.  Warning: no safety checks are in place, and debugfs may fail in interesting ways if commands such as ls,  dump,  etc.  are tried without specifying the data_source_device using the -d option.  debugfs is a debugging tool.  It has rough edges!
Disables  metadata  checksum verification.  This should only be used if you believe the metadata to be correct despite the complaints of e2fsprogs.

If you specify the -s option, you must also provide the blocksize  of  the file  system  via  the  -b option.   (This option is rarely needed; it is used primarily when the file system is extremely badly dam‐ aged/corrupted.)
Specifies that the file system should be opened in read-write mode.  Without this option, the file  system  is  opened  in  read-only mode.

overwriting  a  file  system  block,  write  the  old contents of the block to an undo file.  This undo file can be used with e2undo(8) to restore the old contents of the file system should something go wrong.  If the empty string is passed as  the  undo_file argument,  the  undo file will be written to a file named debugfs-device.e2undo in the directory specified via the E2FSPROGS_UNDO_DIR environment variable.
